hi how's my mic people hear me okay so

before okay there's at least one Go developer in this room so that's still pretty
good uh just a little quick bit about me so I'm one of the Go developers i sit in
the Google instant response team in Mountain View uh I also have an active interest in OS 10 security i was the OS
10 security guy at Google for a while so uh looking after the security of all our Macs and before that I was uh doing a
bunch of pentesting you led a led a bit pentesting team mostly Windows pentesting uh did some instant response
security audits most other security jobs you can imagine so I wanted to start uh
before I kind of explain what Gur is what that acronym actually stands for um
I wanted to start where Gur started which was uh talking about live forensics and I think this really is not
an optional thing anymore I think if you want to defend your network effectively I think you need to have some capability
like this and it doesn't have to be this one but uh I think that being able to
respond uh to the many and different kind of various ways you can be compromised and the many different
environments that we have in our organizations today it's not really an optional thing anymore so I'm going to
go through a couple of use cases to kind of illustrate this so here's uh Joe's machine uh it's
beaconing to somewhere that looks pretty bad uh so it's making these HTTP requests that are probably malware
command and control so okay we want to do something about this so um maybe we
can walk over to the ne next cube and grab Joe's machine and take a memory dump and do some dead disc
forensics but unfortunately that's not going to work because Joe's here right
now uh he's having a really nice time uh off the co the Nepali coast uh in the Hawaiian Islands and he may not be great
at security but he's actually really great at vacations so we can't just walk over to the next cube and pick up his
machine and do what we would normally do so if we have some sort of capability like GR where an agent's already
installed and it can talk over the internet then as long as we he's got internet access so he's got 3G on his
boat there then we can do some sort of initial triage of his machine uh figure out what's going on maybe grab copies of
malware uh and and respond to this threat uh and if we don't do that basically the options are either the
data comes to us or we go to to the data so in this case it would be awesome to go to Hawaii that would be great uh but
uh it's probably not going to scale very well depending on how many instant responders you have and shipping the
machine back is perhaps the other option uh but it's also completely unreliable it might be okay from Hawaii but
consider all the different countries that uh organization might operate in with less reliable shipping uh you know
maybe the disc turns up maybe it doesn't so it'd be great to have an agent there
so another kind of use case I'm going to use to uh talk about G today is that
there's this new AP report out uh whether it's advanced persistent or even a threat might be kind of debatable but
there's this new report uh and you know whether the contents of the report are amazing uh what's pretty much guaranteed
to be amazing is uh code names and logos so uh for the purpose of this report I
have bear eagle shark laser uh which is my apt report code name so there's this
new malware report bear eagle shark laser and we need to check all the things in our whole
organization so this is actually pretty complicated so this report has you know like over 50 indicators of compromise uh
it works on two different uh operating systems and we've got a big organization with tons of different things that uh
that need need to check so doing this without some sort of agent like G is a
really tough proposition so maybe you can make some sort of management tools uh you can kind of uh with a fair bit of
development work perhaps you can make them do the things that you want to do uh in this sort of scenario but really
having a custom design tool that's ready to take on a task like this uh is I think really
important so what is this tool uh so GR stands for GR rapid response it's a
recursive acronym in the best traditions of GNU wine YAML uh
YOLO actually YOLO is not I'm just seeing if people are awake it's not actually a recursive acronym um it works
on Windows Mac and Linux uh it works at scale uh we run it at scale uh it gives
you access to the raw disk and raw memory of machines it's a stable client and a stable server we run this on a lot
of machines uh so and we also do a lot of work to uh make sure that we're not
eating too many system resources so we measure how much CPU how much memory how much network we're consuming uh and we
have limits for each of those things there's a two-party authorization system
um you can so to take any action on a machine uh you can set it up so that it requires approval from uh someone else
uh and we can hunt across large numbers of machines so take some action across the entire fleet so like the uh the bear

GR overview bit I'm going to do so I'm talking all about new kind of new GU

the exact path that we need for the IE browser history on this particular version of Windows uh but it's not

uh it has a bunch of DLS in it a bunch of hashes maybe some registry keys um
all of these indicators especially the hashes are really pretty fragile so you know you think about a hash a
malware hash um you know often people ask me oh you know can GR just tell me if this hash is on a machine um so
hashing is actually kind of really bad for detection i mean a one bit difference is is all it takes right and
so maybe maybe the malware that we get that is actually the same malware uh is just has a different campaign identifier
in it or maybe uh it had a different compile time or maybe it's a slightly newer or slightly older version there's
a million different reasons why the hash is like probably not going to match across malware campaigns right uh and
same thing with with lots of the other indicators here so you know the uh the file system names they might be derived
from uh other files that are actually on the file system so they might be per machine uh specific they might be per
campaign specific uh they could just be random uh and same with the registry keys so given that all of this is pretty
fragile is there kind of like a better way that we could hunt for uh a m for malware like
this what would what would we collect so um so we saw that it wrote into system
32 so we know this thing writes executables and and DLS into system 32 uh so let's just collect all of system
32 uh all the executables and DLS in there so the advantages are that uh we
leak a lot less intel so if we every time we tell uh G to go collect a very specific file path or registry key or
whatever then if that machine is compromised we potentially leak that information to the attacker so now that
maybe they know we're after them uh so if we can just collect a whole bunch of stuff fairly regularly then you know uh
we there's much less intelligence exposed uh and if we do all the analysis on the server side we might uh if if you
did this you might collect a whole bunch of unknown bad so you might 6 months from now you might realize that uh this
particular DL we collected was actually part of a new malware toolkit that we didn't know about at the time uh and as
long as you keep that file around then you'll have this history uh and another time another time to look at to go find
maybe patient zero on your network and the obvious downside is you know there's a ton of files uh so is this actually
really practical so could you do this um in my fairly vanilla Windows development
machine this was like 3 gigs worth of files in system 32 so it is practical to collect large
numbers of files with go um and to do it across uh at scale do it across a lot of
machines and and I'm going to explain why that how that works and kind of why it's effective so uh the first thing to
note is uh that we hash files and we we never retrieve the same uh hash
obviously so if it's identical on the machine it's identical to what we've got in the uh uh in the repository so we can
hash on the machine and then not retrieve it so you can see here uh these kind of malware inspired file names uh
on these two different machines uh the purple file there is bit for-bit identical across the two machines uh but
we also hash we chunk uh files up into blocks and so we also hash each individual block so we if we've already
got this this block of bits on the server then we don't need to retrieve that either so you can see here there's
uh three files across two machines that share a yellow block and there's two files that share a blue block basically
you get the idea that you know we only send uh you know what we don't have and
so in the Ger database files look like just a kind of big array of pointers to all the bits of uh data that we've
retrieved we only store each one of those blocks once so practically like if if you do a
big collection like this you can use the client limits um to make it uh to make
it work so what we do is we use this this client limit here which says for the hunt only run on x number of
machines so we might run it on 10 machines say for something that's really intensive and we'll preede that database
with like 80% of the common files so all the files that are common across system 32 most versions of Windows will
probably get and so then we can run it on a 100 machines and then 500 machines and then we can run it on the entire
fleet and by the time we've run it on the entire fleet we're only collecting a diff of every file every block that we
don't have already um and you can also use the client rate uh limit here to
make sure you don't kill your server at the same time so uh this this is kind of like steps up like how many uh how many
